In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MFAC4001 - Value-Based Health Care in Clinical Practice","description":"

Welcome to Value Based Health Care in Clinical Practice. This course comprises of six units of credit and is a core component of the Year 4 Medicine program. This is a multi-term course run in terms 1, 2 and 3 of the academic calendar with 1 assessment item to be completed in each term.


Students will gain understanding of the health system structures and functions that underpin value-based care frameworks, and through case-based discussions, consider how to deliver appropriate care and lead healthcare change. You will learn how to measure patient outcomes, accurately capture clinical costs, integrate knowledge from diverse datasets and re-design models of care that improve efficiency and create value for patients. Principles of leadership theory, change management and strategic thinking are taught in this course to provide students with the skills to conceptualise, communicate and affect change in their future clinical practice. Finally, you will have the opportunity to learn from the experiences of senior stakeholders in Government and industry regarding designing and implementing effective systems and services that deliver high-value healthcare

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"88ce444bdb81285055a93324f396198d","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be placed into teams of 5-10 at the beginning of the course. Each team will be required to choose one of the thirteen services in Box 5 (below) of the following research study that have been identified as providing ‘Low Value-Care’

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"08ce444bdb81285055a93324f396198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"0cce444bdb81285055a93324f3961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0cce444bdb81285055a93324f3961991","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1cce484bdb81285055a93324f3961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"MCQ Quiz ","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This online quiz will address taught content from Sections 1-3. It will consist of 30 multiple choice questions (MCQs) regarding the structure and financing of the Australian Healthcare System and the concept of value in healthcare.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"04ce444bdb81285055a93324f396198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"04ce444bdb81285055a93324f3961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"04ce444bdb81285055a93324f3961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0cce444bdb81285055a93324f396198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4cce484bdb81285055a93324f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"VBHC Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be provided with a detailed scenario related to working as a junior doctor at a major teaching hospital in Australia. The scenario will incorporate the following elements:

  • The hospital has recently received NSW Health Innovation funding to implement a new service or innovation project related to improving patient care or health service delivery
  • The Executive Board of the Hospital are interested in hearing from clinicians who are interested in participating and leading a clinical service improvement project
  • The Executive Board have shortlisted the following service/innovation projects that they are interested in supporting:
    • Telehealth appointments in outpatient general surgical, orthopaedic and fracture clinics
    • Nurse-practitioner led clinics in the emergency department
    • Use of digital communication devices for front-line clinical staff e.g. replacing pagers, fax machines
    • Electronic prescribing
    • Web-based patient portal to access results and for remote monitoring
    • Clinical decision-making tools and apps
    • Other – students have the option of submitting their own service innovation project to course tutors for approval

Students will be asked to write a project proposal for the Executive Board of the Hospital, outlining why this service / innovation is needed and how it adds value for patients. Part of the proposal will include a detailed project plan that will adopt improvement science and change management methodology taught during the course.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MFAC4501 - Independent Learning Project 1","description":"

The three courses [MFAC 4501, MFAC 4502, MFAC 4503] collectively comprise the Independent Learning Project and must be taken consecutively. After completing Phase 1, all students (unless exempt) will be required to undertake an Independent Learning Project (ILP) equivalent to 3 x 8-week blocks. During the course of the ILP period the students will also complete 12 units of credit (UoC) in courses offered by Faculties other than the Faculty of Medicine to meet General Education Requirements. In order to complete both of these requirements, the 24 week ILP enrolment will be staggered over 4 x 8-week blocks, ie: over 32 weeks. 


Objectives: To enhance students' abilities for independent learning, critical analysis and research. During the course of their ILP the students will be expected to achieve the following specific goals:


  1. An ability and inclination to question the basis of current scientific thinking in relation to medical and public health practice.
  2. To retrieve literature on a topic and demonstrate a familiarity with the use of medical databases.
  3. To evaluate current knowledge in a field and to provide a critical appraisal of that body of knowledge.
  4. To identify a problem in their chosen field and to understand and participate in the process of designing a scientific investigation of the problem.
  5. To be aware of the ethical issues involved in medical research and be able to write an ethics proposal for their proposed study.
  6. To critically evaluate data including the appropriate use and interpretation of statistics.
  7. To communicate findings and interpretations in their chosen field, both orally and in writing with experts, peers, the media and general public.
  8. To appreciate the implications of research findings in health decision making and medical practice.

The ILP will offer scope for in-depth study in a variety of possible settings and fields of study. Some examples include laboratory-based work in the biomedical sciences, audits of clinical practice, projects dealing with cross-cultural issues, as well as projects dealing with medical law or ethics and health economics. 


Although there is considerable flexibility in the choice of topic, all projects must involve;


  1. identification of an issue and related questions relevant to the field or environment where learning will occur; 
  2. a review and critical analysis of literature or practice relevant to the issue;
  3. articulation of an approach to address the issue, including consideration of ethical issues; 
  4. a period of research or scholarship in which the issue is explored or investigated; and 
  5. evaluation, communication and presentation of the results of in-depth study.

During MFAC 4501 and MFAC 4502, a series of lectures, tutorials and workshops will be delivered to introduce students to research methodology in both quantitative and qualitative research projects, to develop skills in statistical analyses and scientific writing.


Assessment will include the components of progressive assessment (on completion of each of the first two 8-week modules i.e. MFAC 4501 and 4502) and a report submitted at the conclusion of the project (i.e. on completion of MFAC 4503). In addition, the supervisor will grade the student's overall performance (at the completion of MFAC 4503)

The two courses [MFAC 4508 and MFAC 4509] collectively comprise the Independent Learning Project and must be taken consecutively. After completing Phase 1, all students (unless exempt) will be required to undertake an Independent Learning Project (ILP). In the same year as the ILP, the students will also complete 12 units of credit (UoC) in courses offered by Faculties other than the Faculty of Medicine to meet General Education requirements and the Clinical Transition course (MFAC 2507). In order to complete these requirements, the 24 week ILP will be staggered over both semesters.

Objectives: To enhance students' abilities for independent learning, critical analysis and research. During the course of their ILP the students will be expected to achieve the following specific goals:
(1) An ability and inclination to question the basis of current scientific thinking in relation to medical and public health practice.
(2) To retrieve literature on a topic and demonstrate a familiarity with the use of medical databases.
(3) To evaluate current knowledge in a field and to provide a critical appraisal of that body of knowledge.
(4) To identify a problem in their chosen field and to understand and participate in the process of designing a scientific investigation of the problem.
(5) To be aware of the ethical issues involved in medical research and be able to write an ethics proposal for their proposed study.
(6) To critically evaluate data including the appropriate use and interpretation of statistics.
(7) To communicate findings and interpretations in their chosen field, both orally and in writing with experts, peers, the media and general public.
(8) To appreciate the implications of research findings in health decision making and medical practice.

The ILP will offer scope for in-depth study in a variety of possible settings and fields of study. Some examples include laboratory-based work in the biomedical sciences, audits of clinical practice, projects dealing with cross-cultural issues, as well as projects dealing with medical law or ethics and health economics.

Although there is considerable flexibility in the choice of topic, all projects must involve;
(1) identification of an issue and related questions relevant to the field or environment where learning will occur;
(2) a review and critical analysis of literature or practice relevant to the issue;
(3) articulation of an approach to address the issue, including consideration of ethical issues;
(4) a period of research or scholarship in which the issue is explored or investigated; and
(5) evaluation, communication and presentation of the results of in-depth study.

During the ILP, a series of lectures, tutorials and workshops will be delivered to introduce students to research methodology in both quantitative and qualitative research projects, to develop skills in statistical analyses and scientific writing.

Assessment will include the components of progressive assessment (on completion of MFAC 4508) and a report submitted at the conclusion of the project (i.e. on completion of MFAC 4509). In addition, the supervisor will grade the student's overall performance (at the completion of MFAC 4509)

At the end of ILP, supervisors will submit a report commenting on the student’s overall performance, and award a mark out of 100 using the grading criteria.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0aa97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ILP 1 Performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Supervisors will be asked to grade the student’s performance during ILP1 by awarding a mark out of 100. This mark will contribute 10% of the students overall ILP mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are asked to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress; these comments will be released to students. Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible. 

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and need go no further. However, where the ILP coordinator feels further action is warranted the ILP coordinator may approach the supervisor, student or seek guidance from the ILP Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

The examiner will grade the final report, awarding the report a mark out of 100 based on the approved grading criteria. This process of review will be at arm’s length from the supervisor and the student. When examining the final report the following attributes should be examined in accordance with the Grading Criteria for the final report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f1a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f9a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"96a97108dbbdf890be4672f5f3961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

The production of the literature review is expected to reflect the culmination of a collaborative process, of review and editing, in which both the student and the supervisor are satisfied that the end product is a scholarly account that accurately reflects the current standing of knowledge in the area of research. The student must demonstrate an active and timely engagement in the preparation, editing and review of the literature review. Students should note that the preparation of a literature review often involves several revisions of their original draft. Therefore, it is important that writing of the review is commenced in a timely manner and feedback from peers is sought – during the ILP this is most likely to be from the supervisor and/or co-supervisor.

 

Late submissions will be referred to the ILP Committee for further consideration.

General Guidelines

·         The literature review is a written, critical review of published information that is relevant to the research project.

·         The literature review should display the following attributes:

·         Appropriate background information provided

·         Covers the main issues in sufficient detail

·         Identifies the areas of controversy and assesses them critically

·         Has clear and logical flow

·         Citation style appropriate and consistent

·         Citation list free of careless errors

·         You should seek guidance from your supervisor as to what topics should or should not be included in your review. It should introduce the broad area of research, review the specific areas that you and your supervisor consider important to your project, and identify controversies and gaps in the literature.

·         One of the most important functions of the literature review is to justify your choice of research topic.

·         A lecture/discussion on writing a literature review forms part of the ILP induction program that will be delivered in week 1.

 

Additional sections required for submission

·         In addition to the review of the literature, students will provide the following three sections (these sections are in addition to the 3000 word limit of the review) that relate to the overall research project

1.    An outline of the main questions to be answered

2.    Hypotheses (if appropriate, and/or aims (up to 1 page))

3.    Brief outline of study design and methods (up to 1 page)

contentlets.description:
The two courses [MFAC 4508 and MFAC 4509] collectively comprise the Independent Learning Project and must be taken consecutively. After completing Phase 1, all students (unless exempt) will be required to undertake an Independent Learning Project (ILP). In the same year as the ILP, the students will also complete 12 units of credit (UoC) in courses offered by Faculties other than the Faculty of Medicine to meet General Education requirements and the Clinical Transition course (MFAC 2507). In order to complete these requirements, the 24 week ILP will be staggered over both semesters.

Objectives: To enhance students' abilities for independent learning, critical analysis and research. During the course of their ILP the students will be expected to achieve the following specific goals:
(1) An ability and inclination to question the basis of current scientific thinking in relation to medical and public health practice.
(2) To retrieve literature on a topic and demonstrate a familiarity with the use of medical databases.
(3) To evaluate current knowledge in a field and to provide a critical appraisal of that body of knowledge.
(4) To identify a problem in their chosen field and to understand and participate in the process of designing a scientific investigation of the problem.
(5) To be aware of the ethical issues involved in medical research and be able to write an ethics proposal for their proposed study.
(6) To critically evaluate data including the appropriate use and interpretation of statistics.
(7) To communicate findings and interpretations in their chosen field, both orally and in writing with experts, peers, the media and general public.
(8) To appreciate the implications of research findings in health decision making and medical practice.

The ILP will offer scope for in-depth study in a variety of possible settings and fields of study. Some examples include laboratory-based work in the biomedical sciences, audits of clinical practice, projects dealing with cross-cultural issues, as well as projects dealing with medical law or ethics and health economics.

Although there is considerable flexibility in the choice of topic, all projects must involve;
(1) identification of an issue and related questions relevant to the field or environment where learning will occur;
(2) a review and critical analysis of literature or practice relevant to the issue;
(3) articulation of an approach to address the issue, including consideration of ethical issues;
(4) a period of research or scholarship in which the issue is explored or investigated; and
(5) evaluation, communication and presentation of the results of in-depth study.

During the ILP, a series of lectures, tutorials and workshops will be delivered to introduce students to research methodology in both quantitative and qualitative research projects, to develop skills in statistical analyses and scientific writing.

Assessment will include the components of progressive assessment (on completion of MFAC 4508) and a report submitted at the conclusion of the project (i.e. on completion of MFAC 4509). In addition, the supervisor will grade the student's overall performance (at the completion of MFAC 4509)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MFAC4888 - Independent Learning Project","description":"

Note: MFAC4888 (10 UOC) is a multi-term course run over 3-terms for a total UOC of 30.


The main aim of the Independent Learning Project (ILP) is to introduce undergraduate medical students to research. Students will undertake a supervised research project that places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/ methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking and scientific communication. Students gain experience in scientific writing and oral presentation via the submission of two written assessments - a Literature Review and a Project Manuscript based on independent research activity-and a 3-minute thesis (3MT). The course is comprised of compulsory online Research Skills Modules (via Moodle), and Departmental/Research Institute/Lab Group seminars (all year round).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"801d4fe41b92a410d5fb0fabdc4bcb22","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Manuscript","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

DESCRIPTION

The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the ILP Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, and 10) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript. This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and references sections, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis or research question section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies and have suggestions for future studies.

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the ILP student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology, Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the ILP student. The referencing style is Numbered.

FEEDBACK

Two examiner reports will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The average of the two examiner marks will be used to obtain an overall mark.

DESCRIPTION

A PowerPoint slide containing a brief introduction, methodology, key results/findings and a discussion of the results. Only ONE (1) static PowerPoint slide is permitted (no slide transitions, animations or ‘movement’ of any description) and the oral presentation is limited to 3 minutes maximum (no poems, raps or songs). No props or additional electronic media allowed (sound and/or video files).   

FEEDBACK

Audience examiners will provide comments and complete a marking rubric. The average mark from all examiners will be used to obtain an overall mark.

DESCRIPTION

Supervisors will grade the student’s performance twice during ILP (Term 1 and Term 3) by awarding a mark out of 100. This mark (5% for each research performance report) will contribute 10% of the student’s overall ILP mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student’s participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the ILP convenor feels further action is warranted the ILP convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the Year 4 Medicine Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

FEEDBACK

Supervisors will complete a marking rubric with comments that will be provided to the students in terms 1 and 3.

DESCRIPTION

The Literature Review is 3,000 words (+/- 10%) and as the name implies, should give a detailed account of published scientific investigations which are relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain the following sections: 1) Introduction, 2) Hypothesis and Aims or Research Questions, 3) Methodology (study design) and 4) Reference List.

The introduction should identify the limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy and assess them critically. It should cite appropriate studies in the field and have clear and logical flow. After introducing the research area/background, the section comprising aims, hypotheses or research questions and methodology is an opportunity to clearly state the research question to be addressed and how this will be achieved. The stated aims should relate to the area(s) outlined in the introduction and the hypotheses should be clear and valid. Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review). If more detail is required for the methodology, this can be added in an Appendix).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, and final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text. The referencing style is Numbered in the Literature Review.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The convener will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiners.

contentlets.description:
Note: MFAC4888 (10 UOC) is a multi-term course run over 3-terms for a total UOC of 30.

The main aim of the Independent Learning Project (ILP) is to introduce undergraduate medical students to research. Students will undertake a supervised research project that places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/ methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking and scientific communication. Students gain experience in scientific writing and oral presentation via the submission of two written assessments - a Literature Review and a Project Manuscript based on independent research activity-and a 3-minute thesis (3MT). The course is comprised of compulsory online Research Skills Modules (via Moodle), and Departmental/Research Institute/Lab Group seminars (all year round).

Note: MFAC4999 (8 UOC) is a multi-term course run over 3-terms for a total UOC of 24.


The main aim of the Independent Learning Project (ILP) is to introduce undergraduate medical students to research. Students will undertake a supervised research project that places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/ methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking and scientific communication. Students gain experience in scientific writing and oral presentation via the submission of two written assessments - a Literature Review and a Project Manuscript based on independent research activity-and a 3-minute thesis (3MT). The course is comprised of compulsory online Research Skills Modules (via Moodle), and Departmental/Research Institute/Lab Group seminars (all year round).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"35656778db6bac10fe4b322af49619fc","name":"Independent research - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Manuscript","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

DESCRIPTION

The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the ILP Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, and 10) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript. This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and references sections, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis or research question section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies and have suggestions for future studies.

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the ILP student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology, Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the ILP student. The referencing style is Numbered.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3165e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3165e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"35656778db6bac10fe4b322af49619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"39656778db6bac10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3965e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7165e778db6bac10fe4b322af4961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Three Minute Thesis (3MT)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

DESCRIPTION

A PowerPoint slide containing a brief introduction, methodology, key results/findings and a discussion of the results. Only ONE (1) static PowerPoint slide is permitted (no slide transitions, animations or ‘movement’ of any description) and the oral presentation is limited to 3 minutes maximum (no poems, raps or songs). No props or additional electronic media allowed (sound and/or video files).   

FEEDBACK

An audience examiner(s) will provide comments and complete a marking rubric. If we have more than one examiner, the average of the examiner marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3165e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3165e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3965e778db6bac10fe4b322af496195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d65e778db6bac10fe4b322af496196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

DESCRIPTION

Supervisor(s) will grade the student’s performance during ILP (Term 3) by awarding a mark based on a rubric. This mark will contribute 10% of the student’s overall ILP mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student’s participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the ILP convenor feels further action is warranted the ILP convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the Year 4 Medicine Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

FEEDBACK

Supervisors will complete a marking rubric with comments that will be provided to the students in Term 3.

DESCRIPTION

Supervisor(s) will grade the student’s performance during ILP (Term 3) by awarding a mark based on a rubric. This mark will contribute 10% of the student’s overall ILP mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student’s participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the ILP convenor feels further action is warranted the ILP convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the Year 4 Medicine Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

FEEDBACK

Supervisors will complete a marking rubric with comments that will be provided to the students in Term 3.

DESCRIPTION

The Literature Review is 3,000 words (+/- 10%) and as the name implies, should give a detailed account of published scientific investigations which are relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain the following sections: 1) Introduction, 2) Hypothesis and Aims or Research Questions, 3) Methodology (study design) and 4) Reference List.

The introduction should identify the limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy and assess them critically. It should cite appropriate studies in the field and have clear and logical flow. After introducing the research area/background, the section comprising aims, hypotheses or research questions and methodology is an opportunity to clearly state the research question to be addressed and how this will be achieved. The stated aims should relate to the area(s) outlined in the introduction and the hypotheses should be clear and valid. Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review). If more detail is required for the methodology, this can be added in an Appendix).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, and final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text. The referencing style is Numbered in the Literature Review.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

contentlets.description:
Note: MFAC4999 (8 UOC) is a multi-term course run over 3-terms for a total UOC of 24.

The main aim of the Independent Learning Project (ILP) is to introduce undergraduate medical students to research. Students will undertake a supervised research project that places emphasis on advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/ methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking and scientific communication. Students gain experience in scientific writing and oral presentation via the submission of two written assessments - a Literature Review and a Project Manuscript based on independent research activity-and a 3-minute thesis (3MT). The course is comprised of compulsory online Research Skills Modules (via Moodle), and Departmental/Research Institute/Lab Group seminars (all year round).
contentlets.title: Independent Learning Project (ILP)
